author: _knarb
content: what is the estimated resulting TPS for both L1 and L2 post-4844?

author: _knarb
content: i've seen conflicting answers but consensus seems to be neglible tps improvements to L1 and a ~100TPS improvement to L2 (from currently 600 to about 700/800)

author: _knarb
content: if thats true, how does the 100 TPS improvement come about i.e. how do you calculate it?

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> There is no canonical way to compute TPS because Rollups can use different forms of compression. 4844 as currently suggested provides 32 kB of data per second. An uncompressed EVM rollup can turn that into about 160 tps. with compression it could be about 10x more or 1600 tps. So something like 160-1600 tps total for rollups from 4844.

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> 4844 is mainly an economic improvement because rollups don't have to compete with L1 transactions anymore

author: bridge-bot
content: <icemelon> > <icemelon>  I wonder if rollups will compete with each other for 4844 blobs given that each block can only hold maximal 6 blobs? (re @dankrad: 4844 is mainly an economic improvement because rollups don't have to compete with L1 transactions anymore)

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> actually 3 on average. Yes rollups will compete for 4844 blobs, just as they compete for calldata now

author: potuz
content: what' s that rollup that can get a 10x compression rate?

author: potuz
content: I wonder if that's purely theoretical or rollups actually are getting that. I thought in practice the batch poster was getting closer to 2x

author: bridge-bot
content: <icemelon> > <icemelon>  true. but the 4844 storage space is more scarse than calldata size (less than half of the size), which may drive the price of data blob to higher and close to calldata price (re @dankrad: actually 3 on average. Yes rollups will compete for 4844 blobs, just as they compete for calldata now)

author: bridge-bot
content: <sauliusgr> 32Kb/s is much more than caldata gives now

author: bridge-bot
content: <icemelon> > <icemelon>  theoretically a block can hold up to 1.8MB of calldata, though avergage at about 90KB. But 4844 can only hold up to 0.75 MB per block and target at 0.375MB (re @sauliusgr: 32Kb/s is much more than caldata gives now)

author: bridge-bot
content: <icemelon> > <icemelon>  actually the block size should be above 100kb now. checked a few recent blocks and all above 100 kb, and some is almost 700 kb (re @sauliusgr: The average block size is ~100kb?)

author: bridge-bot
content: <sauliusgr> I don’t expect that blob space will be dirty cheap, but it should be less expensive than calldata. And the price of calldata should be less then it is now. So sounds like an improvement.
